content.description: Start as low as possible sitting on the inner boulder with hands on right rail and feet hooked on left rail. Compress and climb right rail till you can span the boulder.  Continue to the point of the prow, and rock over the top with solid right heel.
content.protection: Good Landing 2 Pads
content.location: (47.3583410, -88.3313510)  Park at pull off on east side of road between JC & Ice Falls. Enter towards cliffs just south of the thick alder brush. Walk in toward coordinates to find grouping of boulders. It will be on the north side of the grouping.

content.description: Start with both hands on the sloper ledge as shown in the image. Follow the line to the awkward and slabby topout. As of right now, the first ascent believed to be Dane Dingman in summer of 2020. Let me know what you think of it!
content.protection: pad + spotter at top out
content.location: Park on the road parallel to the GPS coordinates and walk in from the road through the wooded boulder field. Located in front of and left of yooper trooper as facing the cliffs from the road. GPS Coordinates: 47°21'30.0"N 88°19'52.0"W

content.description: The rating varies from 5.4 to 5.9 (left to right) on this face of cracks. Left of J.C. Superstar. Great setting for Cliff Dr. Lower from the belay tree and make the climb two pitches.
content.protection: Trad. Bolts possibly up top for TR and/or rappel. Check condition if bolts exist.
content.location: J.C. Area - 1.5 miles south from the north entrance to Cliff Dr. Hike toward the cliffs. Steep hiking. Killer Bees block is located just before the hilltop. Continue past Killer Bees on the right. Gain the hilltop and break left. The top of J.C. and Tobacco Road and is a nice block perch looking out over Cliff Dr.

content.description: Start on the same corner jug that is shared with Bolete then traverse right through the obvious sloped crease that meets up with Thunder Chicken direct. Perform the same crux finish as shared with the direct version toping out on slopers over the lip. If you don't like crimps do this alternate version that skips over the crimpy start. Just as fun as the direct line of Thunder Chicken but adds something extra. Like Thunder Chicken, a must climb area classic. Best conditions in late spring or fall when the rock is less humid.
content.protection: 2-4 pads and 1 or 2 spotters recommended.
content.location: Same as for Thunder Chicken

content.description: Slabby face. Decent tilt.
content.protection: Top Rope. Do not remember any bolts as the guide book describes. Thin pro maybe?
content.location: Top of the Ice Fall area - next to Rated P.G. This is a great rappel to get into the area at the bottom of Rated P.G. and the top of Lie Detector, Ice Fall, and Stoned Cold Liar.

content.description: Start left hand on crimp seam and right hand on crimp gaston using poor feet of choice. Make your way through a couple crimpy moves and a greasy pinch into first jug. Then follow the obvious seam and a powerful move into the next jug followed by intricate movement at the top requiring creative body positions focused around a sidepull with a circular indent within the main seam. Finish on solid slopers over the lip. One of the areas most classic lines, a must do. Best conditions found in late spring or fall when the rock is dry.
content.protection: Solid landing, 2-4 pads and 1 or 2 spotters is recommended.
content.location: Located on the same boulder as bolete, porcupine and dogbowl. Drive ~1 mile from the north entrance and park at tree clearance on left side of the road. Walk almost straight 200 feet in the direction of the cliff and you should be able to see this large boulder through the trees. If you hit the Yooper Trooper or Off-Kilter boulders you have ventured too far left. Make your way 50-100 feet right across the ridge from there. Follow coordinates for bolete for accurate location. This very obvious, tall boulder has a large, shallow hueco in it.

content.description: Straight up the dirty slab to the first roof, pull to the easy slab above.  Angle left up this slab to the left corner under the orange second roof.  Reach out and ascend the bomber flake up to the mantle.  A "thank god" ledge gives you time to sort out the small nuts needed to protect the crux (with bomber placements at your heals) which is the move out right around the 3rd roof.  Get established on the slab above and cruise to the treeded ledge.  At this point you need to choose where to stop.  This is the natural end to the climb and a bomber white pine anchor, but one rope will not get you down, and the pull from the tree is really tough and barely doable  (will be replacing webbing and rap rings.)  Or, you can continue up  the buttress on an easy featured slab and anchor on the white pine about 40' higher.  The rope will pull much easier from this tree.  There is no 4th class approach from either side of the buttress to toprope this route or walk down.  Sometimes has Perrigrine falcons nearby, so avoid if nesting perigrines are giving you the flyby.
content.protection: standard rack, need small nuts/ large micros.
content.location: This route is visible from the road, you can see the orange second roof directly up from the curvey road sign.  You can park there and walk straight up to the climb, navigating a small swamp.  Head up through the boulder field.  This climb is located between Overkill Roof area and JC superstar area.

content.description: This route starts straight up from below the headwall of Exotermic through the triangular roof.  It is the farthest to the left on this face.  The next route to the left is around the corner on Obsession face and that route name is Clavin's project.
content.protection: Little ability to protect until triangular roof.

climbs.name: Stoned Cold Liar (AKA Old Dirty Bastard)

content.description: Up and slanting right then straight and then left to the anchors. Crux is 15-20 ft. before the anchors, the holds thin somewhat and you make a right to left move upward. Look for a block with a neutral grip.
content.protection: Protection could be sketchy on this face with the freeze/thaw from the winter snow. Build an anchor in the same area as for Lie Detector and Ice Fall.
content.location: Just around the corner to the right from Lie Detector. Might need cleaning.

content.description: Off-width to the right of Obsession. Head through the roof.
content.protection: Trad. Top-rope.
content.location: Just left of Obsession Direct.

content.description:
The start is slanted and getting on this climb can prove interesting. The crux pretty much the whole climb. Climb the underclung flake/crack system up and tending left then finishing on slopers up and right. Rope-burn is a great boulder problem-ish climb which needs a TR, or 9-plus crash pads.  

Be aware of the run of your rope on TR.*
content.protection: Top rope by gaining the top of the RB block via a ledge system up and right from the base area of the climb. Lead would be exciting for sure. Thin pro, at best? This short route lends itself to more TR than lead. Be safe, don't deck. Climb on Garth.
content.location: Just uphill of the mossy boulder in the Ice Fall Area. Ice Fall and Lie Detector are 400-500 ft. to the right (north-eastish) from Rope-burn.

content.description: Crux: Gaining the arete and running bolts 1 and 2. This is a sporty fun climb with nice U.P. exposure.   Lead fall decker potential if your belayer is not fully engaged.
content.protection: 4 bolts.
content.location: Top of the Ice Fall area. Above Ice Fall (5.7), Lie Detector (5.8), and Stoned Cold Lier (5.8). Rappel down the slab to the east of the Rated P.G. block/arete to begin Rated P.G. or scramble down to the tops of the above three routes.

content.description: This one is fun, but the ending is kind of lame because you can exit on the slab. There is a potential dyno just left of this Arete. The top would need some scrubbing. Given a generic name beause im sure it has been climbed before.
content.protection: Pad. Spotter.
content.location: South of Mossy Boulder, downhill.

content.description: Start right hand on patina crimp pinch. Left hand on slopey horizontal or in crack. Move left through good edges. Has potential for a lower start, but is scrunchy. Given a generic name because I'm sure it has been done before.
content.protection: Pad. Spotter.
content.location: South of Mossy Boulder, uphill. Faces the road.

content.description: Two hand start on the left side of the bottom horizontal crack. Move up and to the left utilizing the top crack and sharp slopers covered in iron inclusions (they can rip up your finger pads. Great grip!) to a mantle top out. Walk off on the left side of the climb.
content.protection: Bouldering pads
content.location: (47.3592269, -89.3309720). Sort of hard to find but if you walk up the hill towards those coordinates there will be a large 15-20' boulder standing relatively alone in the forest. The route is to the left of the side facing downhill.

content.description: Sit for starting position with both hands either on the obvious rail or pinch jug on the arete. Make your way up the arete while fighting the barndoor using cool pinches and crimps in awkward positions. Fight for jug crimp at the top. This boulder is harder than it looks and will make you wish you had feet where you don't. Crux might just be pulling the first move as you fight the tendency to barndoor and fall back off the angled face. Multiple sessions might be required to work out the beta. If you're crazy, you might just find yourself enjoying this quality line in the end.
content.protection: One or two pads will do. One spotter might be helpful from sliding down the sloped landing.
content.location: A smallish boulder located no more than 30 feet to the right of Yooper Trooper looking up at the cliffs. Road facing problem easily visible hiking roughly 60 feet to the left of the big hueco boulder.

content.description: Tough overhanging face. Watch the pendulum and lead fall potential.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Check condition.
content.location:
Obsession Area. 1/2 mile south of the north junction of Cliff Dr. and U.S. 41. The Obsession Block is obvious from the road . See pictures. Hike up and left of the tailings piles to access the bottoms of many climbs in the area. Or hike uphill and then left to find the top of the Obsession Buttress.  

  Left of Obsession Direct.

content.description: Head left from the lower ledge and up the arret and over the headwall. One bolt after the headwall?
content.protection: Trad. Mixed. Top-Rope
content.location: bsession Area. 1/2 mile south of the north junction of Cliff Dr. and U.S. 41. The Obsession Block is obvious from the road. See pictures. Hike up and left of the tailings piles. Hike up and left to the top  of the hill and find the top of Obsession. Or hike lower and access the bottoms of many climbs on the area.

content.description: Start from the ledge (15' above the ground) at the bottom of the lower slab. Head up right or left. Head past the small overhang and then the big one. Piton (if still remaining) was placed in 1981.
content.protection: Trad. Natural anchors and pro placement.
content.location: Obsession Area. 1/2 mile south of the north junction of Cliff Dr. and U.S. 41. The Obsession Block is obvious from the road. See pictures. Hike up and left of the tailings piles. Hike up and left to the top  of the hill and find the top of Obsession. Or hike lower and access the bottoms of many climbs on the area.

content.description: Squat start on sloping crimp rail with terrible feet. Pull through to holds trending toward prow. Top out on moss covered holds (needs a good scrub). Given a generic problem name because I'm sure it has been climbed before. Obvious line with hard opening moves. It's even hard to establish on the start hold. Stand start is about V4.
content.protection: Two pads and a spotter would be nice. Sharp blocks in the landing.
content.location: Mossy Boulder.

content.description: Sit start and traverse the lip. Lowball.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location: South of Mossy Boulder.

content.description: Begin on the leaning slab and in the crack. Crux is pulling the roof. Finish 10-15 ft. after the roof.
content.protection: Traditional protection. Standard rack. Or top rope from above.
content.location: Ice Fall Area - 2 miles south of the northern Cliff Dr. junction with US 26/41 just before Phoenix. Locate large mossy boulder in the lower flats in the woods just prior to the hillside rising. There are many boulders, but this one stands out a bit. Hike uphill a few hundred feet. Approach from either above or below. Continue to the top of the cliffs and hike east then rappel in on the right (east) side of Rated P.G. and walk down the trail to the tops of Ice Fall and Lie Detector. Or find the talus field at the bottom and hike east skirting the cliff outcroppings. Beware of poison ivy!

content.description: Start up a flat featureless slab for the first 20 ft.  Hug the right side arete, as that's where most of your initial protection can be found.  Pull over a small roof/shelf and work your way left to two obvious large crescent shaped cracks.  Balancy to the top.
content.protection: Cams of just about any size will work on the crack, but it seems like having a fistful of BD #1's it the way to go.  Set up on belay ledge same as Dandruff.

content.description: Nice face climb perched above the forests of da U.P. eh! Cracks and ledges help your way. Variations on this one.
content.protection: Top-rope. Maybe thin pro? Scope it out on rappel.
content.location: J.C. Area - 1.5 miles south from the north entrance to Cliff Dr. Hike toward the cliffs. Steep hiking. Killer Bees block is located in the trees just before the hill kicks up steeply. Continue past Killer Bees on the right. Gain the hilltop and break left. The top of J.C. and Tobacco Road and is a nice block perch looking out over Cliff Dr.

content.description:
Slab climbing Keweenaw style! No real crux. Fun warm up climb.  

*Ice climbing in the past on Ice Fall (go figure) when the conditions are right.
content.protection: Thin pro on lead. No bolts. Natural anchor. The top puts you at to the path/rock ledges in between the top of Ice Fall and Rated P.G.
content.location: Ice Fall Area - 2 miles south of the northern Cliff Dr. junction with US 26/41 just before Phoenix. Locate large mossy boulder in the lower flats in the woods just prior to the hillside rising. There are many boulders, but this one stands out a bit. Hike uphill a few hundred feet. Approach from either above or below. From below cross a talus field and broken cliff edges, watch for poison ivy. Or continue to the top of the cliffs and hike east then rappel in on the right (east) side of Rated P.G. which is Tip Toes. Walk down the trail to the tops of Ice Fall and Lie Detector from here.

content.description: Left hand start in a low triangle right pulling crimp, right hand off to the right on a slopey crimp. Cross over and work your way up the splitter cracks to sideways crimp at the top. Keep an eye out for a potential thumbpress. Finish on a good ledge. V1 for tall people, slightly harder for shorter folks.
content.location: Park on the road parallel to the GPS coordinates and walk in from the road through the wooded boulder field. Located in front of and left of yooper trooper as facing the cliffs from the road. GPS Coordinates: 47°21'30.0"N 88°19'52.0"W Located on western face of the same boulder as "Twenty-year-old Trembling"

content.description: Fight the steep offwidth to the first ledge, then transfer into the traversing finger crack, then fight your way up the long offwidth to the top.  Rap down gully, no anchors.
content.protection: Bring a few wide pieces.
content.location: Between Overkill Roof and Three Roofs.  (47.36008, -88.33134)

content.description: Climb up the left side of the block and gain the horizontal right-left tending crack. Move right all the way to the end and exit onto the face above.
content.protection: Trad. Or TR from above.
content.location: The Diamond Block - 1.85 miles south of the north junction of Cliff Dr. and U.S. 41. Scout out a path through the talus field.

content.description: A large tower/buttress coming out of the wall just to the northeast of the ice falls area.  Good protection every 10-15 feet, variety of gear sizes needed.  Top rope access extremely difficult/impossible.  Excellent learner piece for first time leaders.  Can top out by traversing the top of the tower back to the wall and climbing the sides of a very steep, scree filled gully.  Climb the gully walls, not the gully itself, as it is NOT STABLE and has FATAL FALL potential.
content.protection: Climbed with rack of Trango Flex #1-4, Metolius Masters #1,2,4, BD #2, omega nuts 1-13 and metolius hex 1-10.  (obviously) did not use them all, but didn't record what was placed.  2 large white pines on route facilitate 2 stage, single rope rappels.
content.location: Spot the tower from the base of the road.  You'll have to fight through thick tag alder and pick your way up the boulder field.  Directly left of Overkill roofs.  Tower to the left of Free to Roam that looks like it has excellent route potential.

content.description: The most northerly climb in the Obsession area, just north of Catholic girls.  A face with deceptively small holds.  Stick to the right side.  All balance.
content.protection: Top rope

content.description: Starts on the left face in the chimney.  Move left at the horizontal groove to gain the headwall above a desperate precipice.
content.protection: No ability to protect on lead.

content.description: Start with left hand on low sidepull, and right in a shallow pocket. Work up obvious seam before traversing right on slopey edges, and throw right for the jug. Good movement on cool holds, tricky but not bad with the right beta.Too nice of a line to not have been done before, but I gave it a name anyways cause it deserves one. Reach out with FA or original name.
content.protection: 1-2 Pads
content.location: On the west face of the large slab boulder south of Old Mossy.

content.description: Two hand start on the middle point of the bottom horizontal crack. Move straight up utilizing the above horizontal crack, slant cracks, and nice sloped lip up to a mantle top out. There's a big dish at the top you can use to help mantle but be warned, it collects water in wetter conditions. Walk off on the left side of the climb.
content.location: (47.3592269, -89.3309720). Sort of hard to find but if you walk up the hill towards those coordinates there will be a large 15-20' boulder standing relatively alone in the forest. The route is to the left of the side facing downhill.

content.description: Sit start under the small roof using shallow pocket to start. Move in and left through good crimps. Pull the roof to the shallow edge, don't use lose sharp left lip. Traverse right on obvious edge to top on the right ridge.   Flat landing with one sharp rock.
content.location: Located 200 yards down trail at JC parking lot. Walk down into the swamp and it is the farthest north boulder.

content.description: On the face directly below the large, woodpecker ridden red pine.  Large flakes and a good crack.  Very juggy, good for beginners.
content.protection: Nuts hold extremely well in the crack, and you can safely protect the thing in about three pieces.

content.description: Start with a high foot and press down with the right hand. Stand up, and repeat on several slopey ledges to reach the top. Best friction slab I've found in the U.P.
content.protection: Pad/spotter let's you bail safely, but an uncontrolled fall would be very bad at most points in this climb
content.location: Slab on the right face of the large boulder

content.description: Start left hand on sidepull to the right of obvious jug rail and right hand on crimp gaston to the left of the arete. Pull a move into the crimp just above you, then work the arete to the crux at the top. Use intricate balance/mantle beta or huck for the mega jug at the top to reach the topout.
content.protection: solid landing. 2-4 pads recommended
content.location: Same as for Thunder Chicken

content.description: Second slab as you hike in on the trail. Dished face climb.
content.protection: Top-rope.
content.location: Obsession Area. 1/2 mile south of the north junction of Cliff Dr. and U.S. 41. The Obsession Block is obvious from the road. See pictures. Hike up and left of the tailings piles. Hike up and left to the top  of the hill and find the top of Obsession. Or hike lower and access the bottoms of many climbs on the area.

content.description: Sit start on two crimps and work the compression feature on bubble wrap holds. Top out, and then top out again. Great rock quality and clean. Given a generic name because I'm sure it has been climbed before.
content.protection: Pad. Spotter.
content.location: Just south of Mossy Boulder.

content.description: An easy out for Killer Bees up a small crack on the left side of the face.  Good first lead.
content.protection: Small cams, two rappel anchors at the top if you want to top rope it.

content.description: Lowball boulder. Start on the crack and crimp to the left. Move up through the crack and top out.
content.protection: 1 Pad
content.location:
Follow the trail to the south-west of the Cliff Mine tailings pile up to the top of the cliff. Boulder is right next to a small stream.

 Coordinates: 47º22'25.6"N 88º18'57.6"W

content.description: Obvious & fun right leaning crack into crux arete finish to solid top ledge. Solve the mystery of which holds are actually good on the arete.
content.protection: 2-3 Pads, alright landing.
content.location: Part of the yooper trooper grouping of boulders.  Park just past left pull out, walk in to base of the scree. 50 yards left of yooper trooper.

content.description: Two hand start on the bottom horizontal crack at the nose of this boulder. Utilize the top horizontal crack and the chossy looking growth on the right to straddle and climb straight up the nose. Some nice big moves get you to an easy mantle up top. Walk off to the left of this route.
content.location: (47.3592269, -89.3309720). Sort of hard to find but if you walk up the hill towards those coordinates there will be a large 15-20' boulder standing relatively alone in the forest. The route is to the left of the side facing downhill.

content.description: Two pitch route, or make it one. Fun little cruiser climb.
content.protection: Bolts for most of the route. Check the bolt conditions due to freeze/thaw exposure and/or lack of use. Might be spots for some traditional protection.
content.location: Approx. 150 yards to the right (northeast) of Stoned Cold Liar.

content.description: Good crack up to small roof.  Deceptively few holds coming over.  Cracks can be difficult to protect due to flare.
content.protection: bring a large nut of BD2 cam to sink into the roof.
content.location: When the JC trail begins to head up the gully, break off to the left until you hit the first roof.

content.description:
Secluded, 20-150+ ft. grey basalt cliff outcroppings. Awesome climbing experience in the isolated Keweenaw Peninsula. Great beginner crags and a handful of classics for the seasoned vet. Be aware of the private property boundaries along Cliff Drive. Watch for poison ivy and ticks. These two nasties are not pervasive but present. Loose dogs can get skunked, porcupined, or picked up by the sheriff. Some of the approaches and/or climbs might be vegetated due to a lack of traffic. Fall colors are amazing. Hopefully the Aurora Borealis will put on a show if you're camping in the Keweenaw.

 *Guidebook for this area exists - Published in the past by Michigan Technological University - Ridge Roamers Climbing Club; "Climber's Guide to the Keweenaw".

 *If someone is/knows the First Ascent parties please contact Big-Time-Small-Timer.

 There are approximately 66 known and documented routes at Cliff Drive.

 Areas are listed in order as you would come across them driving northeast along Cliff Dr.

 - Ice Fall Area (19 routes) - Diamond Block (3 routes) - Overkill Roof (Unknown) - Brave Words Block (2 routes) - Free to Roam Block (1 route) - J.C. Area (17 routes) - Obsession Area (20 routes) - Tower Area (4 routes)
